narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-14, if you wish
comments: This was my favorite class of the semester.

Rob Bailis is a BAMF. It's a close call, but I think Bailis is the best professor I had at FES. He's wise like Seto or Grubler without the arrogance, and he's as creative as I'm sure Graedel was before age took its toll.The class would go from great to phenomenal if there was as field trip to a developing country to look at energy.

narratives.question_text: What were the best aspects of this course?
comments: In class discussions and Homer Assignment

The reading material is interesting and relevant and the Professor brings a lot of real-world experience to the classroom and is able to provide a genuine insight into Energy Issues in Developing Countries. The course provides an overview of several of the current problems in developing countries.

Towards the end of the class, I realized I had learnt a lot from the class -The HOMER modeling exercise was very valuable in terms of understanding a holistic view of energy issues.The classroom discussion sections were informal and allowed space for free expression - I could participate despite usually feeling intimidated.

This is one of the few classes that discusses the Homer model which is very valuable. I liked the emphasis on writing an interdisciplinary focus for the final paper. The discussion sections were very valuable but the time alotted for them was sometimes insufficient. Guest speakers (both Douglas Barnes and Chris Hebdon) were great.
The readings.

I like how much the class covered. I would like a little more information on how we might apply the information in our jobs. Many of us are going to work for governments, NGOs, etc., that work on energy issues, so I would like more info on how material could be used in those positions.
HOMER project. Some lectures were really great.
HOMER modeling project, thoughtful feedback on weekly writing, the way the class was organized to look at issues from the household to global scale

narratives.question_text: What aspects of this course need the most improvement?
comments: Sometimes the material is too rushed and I would suggest selecting a few topics and exploring them more deeply. I would also modify the lecture style to be more engaging and interactive by asking students to do the research and present some of the material (with guidance from Prof. Bailis). I would also encourage the Professor to test the students more frequently to ensure that they actually learn the material.All too often at FES, it's easy to skim the reading material without really absorbing or learning anything beyond the period of the course. More rigorous testing (like written exams) ensure that students actually study in order to learn.

It would be great if we could have pointers or suggestive prompts about for reading responses. It would help make all the class think in the direction that the lecturer expects us to - for each set of readings. Or perhaps have a question for each week that the lecturer would like us to answer by critical analysis of the readings.

Don't bring back the Ph.D student that guest lectured while Bailis was gone on week. He was unprepared and terrible.The class discussions were mostly unhelpful. I would instead like the last hour or half hour to spent discussing the issues in way that doesn't include silly role playing. We didn't learn much in the unrealistic scenarios. I would rather that time be put to better use actually having a debate or discussion about the topics at hand.
Need to always allow enough time for the simulation exercises, adjust time per slide in lectures accordingly.
Outdated materials in the weekly reading assignments

narratives.question_text: Was the relationship between the course lectures and discussion/lab section
comments: The discussions are often bordering on mediocre. I would replace the discussions with student presentations (individual or in pairs) on specific topics. That way, students learn as they prepare the presentations and other students pay more attention as they get to learn about different topics in more details from their classmates. It also adds variety and generates interest.

The flexibility of the discussion sections allowed for creativity. One of the discussion sections was a quiz, some of them were role plays. All of them created different types of value.The quiz was quite interesting because it gave a chance for a refresher and a overall review of what was taught in class. This could be great for retention of takeaways. Students could be suggested to alternate between role plays and quizzes of they do not mind taking suggestions from the TA.

The discussion section was good but there was not enough alotted time to have indepth discussions. I would suggest that instead of a reading response prior to class, a follow up response after the discussion would be more valuable since it would give student the opportunity to reflect on the discussion and the lectures and give well thought out solutions/memos.
The quality of the discussions varied week to week.
Yes, the relationship was effective.
The student-led discussion section could have benefitted from more moderation by or insights from the instructor.

narratives.question_text: What were the strengths and weaknesses of your teaching assistant
comments: Alark was a good TA. He's fun and engaging and very prompt about following up on any issues. I would encourage him to teach more!
Instructor: Alark Saxena  I liked the comments I received for my reading responses.
Instructor: Alark Saxena  Alark was involved in all the discussions and was available for providing feedback. He did a good job mediating some of the discussion sections and providing his input.
Instructor: Alark Saxena  I like Alark a lot. He's very helpful and I'd jump at the chance to take another class with him.
Instructor: Alark Saxena  Knew the subject, thoughtful responses to papers and questions. I don't think it could be improved. FES should hire him as professor.

narratives.question_text: Discuss, if you wish, how this course fits into your overall program.  (Please feel free to describe how the course relates to your academic background.)
comments: As an international student from Pakistan, this course was very relevant to my personal background and my career aspirations as I hope to work on projects to resolve some of the large energy poverty issues in developing countries with a specific focus on South Asia. I found the readings very helpful and also used this course to jumpstart my summer research which I am conducting in Pakistan under Prof. Bailis's guidance.

I am very interested in electrification in developing countries and this course focused on that aspect significantly. Also, the Homer model is a very valuable tool and this class provided a good medium to work with that tool.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: Strong interest in energy issues in developing countries
Energy modeling with HOMER, learning more about other countries issues with Energy is very interesting.
Primarily to learn about opportunities for decentralized renewables and micro grids.

narratives.question_text: Did the knowledge/skills that you gained from the course meet your expectations ?
comments: Yes, completely.
Yes.
Yes, it met my expectations
Yes.
Yes.
Yes.
Yes

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: Working on Homer assignment was a great learning experience.

I was lucky to be part of a very motivated group with very interesting and diverse academic and professional backgrounds. We were able to collaborate and bring our strengths to the table and got a good grade on the project.
We worked as a group on the homer model and the group discussions were very valuable
Advantages were that I got to work with fellow students. Disadvantages were that I felt some members of my group did not put in enough effort into the exercise.
The project was cool; I liked using Homer. It was the kind of thing we might actually do in a job setting. That's the kind of thing FES needs more of.
Slower than individual work, but easier to kept deadlines.
I had the opportunity to work with someone from Global Affairs, which brought a different perspective to our project. I didn't experience any disadvantages to the group (partner) project.

narratives.question_text: For students who might consider taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: It's a good class and Rob is a great person to work with. However, you should plan on taking advantage of office hours and discuss your goals with him. He's much more helpful in a one-on-one setting.

Definitely take this course! Social, economic, cultural and historic aspects of energy are discussed, whose importance is often overlooked in other energy courses. The HOMER software is a great exercise as well.The workload is just right.If you are European or American, do team up with people from other (developing) countries for discussions for valuable perspectives.
Take it because Bailis is great and HOMER is energy modeling, which we need more of at FES
